newsitem.title: GERMANY: FEATURE - Will palmtop PCs be a hit in Europe?
newsitem.headline: FEATURE - Will palmtop PCs be a hit in Europe?

text.p: Europeans will be able to get their hands on a new generation of palm-sized computers this month, but even the computer industry's hype may not convince many to pocket them.

Six "PC companions" -- the first true Windows PCs in a palmtop package -- hit the market in the United States late last year and are due to be shown in Europe for the first time at Hanover's CeBIT computer fair from March 13-19.

But analysts say European techno-scepticism, poorly developed communications links, tiny keyboards, and the lingering shadow of Apple Computer Inc's spectacular Newton flop of 1994 -- were likely to keep the little machines from making a big splash.
"For technophiles, they are neat little gadgets," said James Bates at market researcher Context in London. "But it's still hard to see how they would appeal to the average person."

Six manufacturers have lined up to make handheld devices running the Windows CE software that Microsoft Corp developed to power a generation of pocket computers which use programmes that look and feel like familiar desktop PC software.
COMPAQ Computer Corp, Hewlett-Packard Co and Philips Electronics NV planned to show off the products at CeBIT, although they won't appear in European stores until later this year.
Japan's Casio Computer Co Ltd and NEC Corp and Korea's LG International Co Ltd also expected to have palmtops in Europe this year.
WHAT THEY LOOK LIKE AND WHAT THEY CAN DO
The machines weigh about 13 ounces, run for 20 hours on a pair of AA batteries and should sell for about 1,200 marks ($709).

Windows CE, a compact version of Windows 95, runs spreadsheets, electronic mail and calendar programmes that look just like those on full-grown computers -- so users can have PCs in their pockets anytime, anywhere.

Compaq, the world's largest PC maker, thinks Windows compatibility will keep PC companions from repeating the Newton disaster, when Apple promised "personal digital assistants" would read human hand-writing, send faxes, and turn millions of people into computer-carrying converts.
"This product offers everything Newton was supposed to be," CEO Eckard Pfeiffer told Reuters, although the Compaq PC Companion C120 does not read hand-writing.

Consumers, technology freaks and especially corporate road warriors -- those traveling salespeople who latch onto any technology that can help close a deal -- should be drawn in by the familiarity of Windows, Pfeiffer said.
"This is not an experiment. I think it will be both a mass market product and a corporate product," he said.
Compaq was shipping thousands of PC Companions per month in the United States and was getting more orders than expected, he added.
ANALYSTS GUARDED
But analysts aren't ready to declare another computer revolution is at hand.

"People didn't really have a great need for Newton, and whether there is a major market now still remains to be seen," Bates said. "I'm not sure these products are much more than electronic date books."

Dataquest's Chris Jones agreed, in particular because Europeans already have digital GSM cellular phones, which can send e-mail, files and faxes from portable PCs. The analog cellular systems in the U.S. can't handle data reliably.
"Who needs a PC companion if you have a GSM phone?" Jones said. "The GSM factor is a big one."

And limitations remain: little black-and-white screens, tiny keyboards and a shortage of data storage mean PC companions won't be up to the same kind of tasks as their desk-bound cousins, the analysts say.
On top of that, Europeans are more technology-shy than U.S. buyers, Jones said. "Acceptance of technology has become quicker, but these products should do better in the U.S."
Even Hewlett Packard, which has sold palmtop PCs for six years, thinks the current market is limited to professionals like roving doctors and researchers collecting data in the field.
"This is not a revolution," said Sharon Coleman, HP's handheld product manager. "The volumes for these products are nowhere near PC volumes. The consumer buy will be rare."
But the Newton vision of handheld devices wirelessly transmitting data from cafes and conference rooms would come eventually, she said.
"We are entering the Internet century and the technology will get better," Coleman explained. "The home market is at least five years away, but this is the future of computing."
($ = 1.693 German Marks)
